Headline: Rail200 on the Southern
Text: Key Events on the Southern Railway, its predecessors and successors
Media Credit: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Surrey Iron Railway Opens,
Text:
The world's first public railway, a horse-drawn plateway, opened between Wandsworth and Croydon.

Designed for freight transport, it connected industries to the River Thames.

Used flanged iron rails on stone sleepers, setting a precedent for later railways.

Although short-lived, it influenced early railway development.
Media Caption: Plaque and original stone sleepers of the Surrey Iron Railway set in the wall of Youngs Brewery in Wandsworth
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Canterbury & Whitstable Railway Opens
Text:
One of the earliest passenger railways in England, running between Canterbury and Whitstable.

Featured the locomotive "Invicta," built by Robert Stephenson.

Included a tunnel with a stationary steam engine for assisted inclines.

Later absorbed into the South Eastern Railway in 1844.
Media Credit: Archives State Agency, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: London and Southampton Railway Opens (Later LSWR)
Text:
Connected London to the key port city of Southampton, boosting trade and travel.

Originally built as a single-track line but later expanded.

Played a crucial role in developing the London & South Western Railway (LSWR).

Enabled rapid movement of goods and passengers between the capital and the south coast.
Media Credit: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Media Caption: London & South Western Railway (LSWR) 4-4-0 460 class No. 467
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: London, Brighton & South Coast Railway (LBSCR) Formed
Text:
Created through the merger of smaller railway companies.

Established direct services from London to Brighton and the Sussex coast.

Known for the famous Brighton Belle luxury train service.

Key driver of commuter railway expansion in the South East.
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Formation of the South Eastern and Chatham Railway (SECR)
Text:
Formed by merging two competing railway companies to improve efficiency.

Operated key routes from London to Kent and the Channel ports.

Introduced electrification schemes and improved suburban services.

Later became part of the Southern Railway in 1923.
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Southern Railway Formed
Text:
Combined LSWR, LBSCR, and SECR into one large regional operator.

Pioneered railway electrification, especially on commuter routes.

Managed key routes to the south coast, including Dover and Portsmouth.

Remained a dominant player until nationalization in 1948.
Media Credit: Elliot and Fry, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Introduction of the 4COR Electric Units
Text:
Designed to modernize Southern Railway's commuter services.

Offered faster and more efficient travel on electrified routes.

Widely used on services from London to the South Coast.

Marked a shift toward electric traction in British railways.
Media Caption: Waterloo - Portsmouth express 4-COR set passing Weybridge
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: Opening of the Channel Tunnel
Text:
Connected the UK to mainland Europe via a 31-mile rail tunnel.

Eurostar services provided high-speed travel between London, Paris, and Brussels.

Facilitated international freight movement and economic integration.

One of the largest engineering projects of the 20th century.
Media Credit: The original uploader was Tambo at Hungarian Wikipedia., CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

Headline: High-Speed 1 (HS1) Opens
Text:
Created the first UK high-speed rail corridor.

Reduced travel times between London and the Channel Tunnel.

Serves Eurostar, Southeastern high-speed trains, and international services.

Transformed rail travel between the UK and Europe.
Burl: See page for author, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
